SourceProxy.Documentation: The Tetrahedralize filter converts the 3D cells of any type of dataset to tetrahedrons and the 2D ones to triangles. This filter always produces unstructured grid output.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Tetrahedralize filter.

SourceProxy.name: TransformFilter
SourceProxy.label: Transform

Documentation.long_help: This filter applies transformation to the polygons.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Transform filter allows you to specify the position, size, and orientation of polygonal, unstructured grid, and curvilinear data sets.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Transform filter.

ProxyProperty.name: Transform
ProxyProperty.Documentation: The values in this property allow you to specify the transform (translation, rotation, and scaling) to apply to the input dataset.

SourceProxy.name: TriangleFilter
SourceProxy.label: Triangulate

Documentation.long_help: This filter converts polygons and triangle strips to basic triangles.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Triangulate filter decomposes polygonal data into only triangles, points, and lines. It separates triangle strips and polylines into individual triangles and lines, respectively. The output is polygonal data. Some filters that take polygonal data as input require that the data be composed of triangles rather than other polygons, so passing your data through this filter first is useful in such situations. You should use this filter in these cases rather than the Tetrahedralize filter because they produce different output dataset types. The filters referenced require polygonal input, and the Tetrahedralize filter produces unstructured grid output.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Triangulate filter.

SourceProxy.name: TubeFilter
SourceProxy.label: Tube

Documentation.long_help: Convert lines into tubes. Normals are used to avoid cracks between tube segments.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Tube filter creates tubes around the lines in the input polygonal dataset. The output is also polygonal.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Tube filter.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputScalars
StringVectorProperty.label: Scalars
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the name of the scalar array on which to operate. The indicated array may be used for scaling the tubes. (See the VaryRadius property.)

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputVectors
StringVectorProperty.label: Vectors
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the name of the vector array on which to operate. The indicated array may be used for scaling and/or orienting the tubes. (See the VaryRadius property.)

IntVectorProperty.name: NumberOfSides
IntVectorProperty.label: Number of Sides
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property indicates the number of faces around the circumference of the tube.

IntVectorProperty.name: Capping
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If this property is set to 1, endcaps will be drawn on the tube. Otherwise the ends of the tube will be open.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Radius
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property sets the radius of the tube. If the radius is varying (VaryRadius property), then this value is the minimum radius.

IntVectorProperty.name: VaryRadius
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The property determines whether/how to vary the radius of the tube. If varying by scalar (1), the tube radius is based on the point-based scalar values in the dataset. If it is varied by vector, the vector magnitude is used in varying the radius.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: RadiusFactor
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: If varying the radius (VaryRadius property), the property sets the maximum tube radius in terms of a multiple of the minimum radius. If not varying the radius, this value has no effect.

SourceProxy.name: WarpScalar
SourceProxy.label: Warp (scalar)

Documentation.long_help: This filter moves point coordinates along a vector scaled by a point attribute. It can be used to produce carpet plots.
Documentation.short_help: Warp point scalars into a spatial elevation plot.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Warp (scalar) filter translates the points of the input data set along a vector by a distance determined by the specified scalars. This filter operates on polygonal, curvilinear, and unstructured grid data sets containing single-component scalar arrays. Because it only changes the positions of the points, the output data set type is the same as that of the input. Any scalars in the input dataset are copied to the output, so the data can be colored by them.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Warp (scalar) filter.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputScalars
StringVectorProperty.label: Scalars
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property contains the name of the scalar array by which to warp the dataset.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: ScaleFactor
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The scalar value at a given point is multiplied by the value of this property to determine the magnitude of the change vector for that point.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Normal
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The values of this property specify the direction along which to warp the dataset if any normals contained in the input dataset are not being used for this purpose. (See the UseNormal property.)

IntVectorProperty.name: UseNormal
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If point normals are present in the dataset, the value of this property toggles whether to use a single normal value (value = 1) or the normals from the dataset (value = 0).

IntVectorProperty.name: XYPlane
IntVectorProperty.label: XY Plane
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If the value of this property is 1, then the Z-coordinates from the input are considered to be the scalar values, and the displacement is along the Z axis. This is useful for creating carpet plots.

SourceProxy.name: WarpVector
SourceProxy.label: Warp (vector)

Documentation.long_help: This filter displaces point coordinates along a vector attribute. It is useful for showing mechanical deformation.
Documentation.short_help: Warp (displace) the geometry with a given vector field.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Warp (vector) filter translates the points of the input dataset using a specified vector array. The vector array chosen specifies a vector per point in the input. Each point is translated along its vector by a given scale factor. This filter operates on polygonal, curvilinear, and unstructured grid datasets. Because this filter only changes the positions of the points, the output dataset type is the same as that of the input.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Warp (vector) filter.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputVectors
StringVectorProperty.label: Vectors
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property contains the name of the vector array by which to warp the dataset's point coordinates.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: ScaleFactor
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Each component of the selected vector array will be multiplied by the value of this property before being used to compute new point coordinates.

SourceProxy.name: Cut
SourceProxy.label: Slice

Documentation.long_help: This filter slices a data set with a plane. Slicing is similar to a contour. It creates surfaces from volumes and lines from surfaces.

SourceProxy.Documentation: This filter extracts the portion of the input dataset that lies along the specified plane. The Slice filter takes any type of dataset as input. The output of this filter is polygonal data.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Slice filter.

ProxyProperty.name: CutFunction
ProxyProperty.label: Slice Type
ProxyProperty.Documentation: This property sets the parameters of the slice function.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: ContourValues
DoubleVectorProperty.label: Slice Offset Values
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The values in this property specify a list of current offset values. This can be used to create multiple slices with different centers. Each entry represents a new slice with its center shifted by the offset value.

SourceProxy.name: ExtractGeometry
SourceProxy.label: Extract Cells by Region

Documentation.long_help: This filter extracts cells that are inside/outside a region or at a region boundary.
Documentation.short_help: Extract cells that are inside/outside a region or at a region boundary.

SourceProxy.Documentation: This filter extracts from its input dataset all cells that are either completely inside or outside of a specified region (implicit function). On output, the filter generates an unstructured grid. To use this filter you must specify a region (implicit function). You must also specify whethter to extract cells lying inside or outside of the region. An option exists to extract cells that are neither inside or outside (i.e., boundary).

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Slice filter.

ProxyProperty.name: ImplicitFunction
ProxyProperty.label: Intersect With
ProxyProperty.Documentation: This property sets the region used to extract cells.

IntVectorProperty.label: Extraction Side
IntVectorProperty.name: ExtractInside
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This parameter controls whether to extract cells that are inside or outside the region.

IntVectorProperty.name: Extract only intersected
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This parameter controls whether to extract only cells that are on the boundary of the region. If this parameter is set, the Extraction Side parameter is ignored. If Extract Intersected is off, this parameter has no effect.

IntVectorProperty.name: Extract intersected
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This parameter controls whether to extract cells that are on the boundary of the region.

SourceProxy.name: Clip

Documentation.long_help: Clip with an implicit plane. Clipping does not reduce the dimensionality of the data set. The output data type of this filter is always an unstructured grid.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Clip filter cuts away a portion of the input data set using an implicit plane. This filter operates on all types of data sets, and it returns unstructured grid data on output.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the dataset on which the Clip filter will operate.

ProxyProperty.name: ClipFunction
ProxyProperty.label: Clip Type
ProxyProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the parameters of the clip function (an implicit plane) used to clip the dataset.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputScalars
StringVectorProperty.label: Scalars
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: If clipping with scalars, this property specifies the name of the scalar array on which to perform the clip operation.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Value
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: If clipping with scalars, this property sets the scalar value about which to clip the dataset based on the scalar array chosen. (See SelectInputScalars.) If clipping with a clip function, this property specifies an offset from the clip function to use in the clipping operation. Neither functionality is currently available in ParaView's user interface.

IntVectorProperty.name: InsideOut
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If this property is set to 0, the clip filter will return that portion of the dataset that lies within the clip function. If set to 1, the portions of the dataset that lie outside the clip function will be returned instead.

IntVectorProperty.name: UseValueAsOffset
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If UseValueAsOffset is true, Value is used as an offset parameter to the implicit function. Otherwise, Value is used only when clipping using a scalar array.

SourceProxy.name: Threshold

Documentation.long_help: This filter extracts cells that have point or cell scalars in the specified range.
Documentation.short_help: Extract cells that satisfy a threshold criterion.

SourceProxy.Documentation:
The Threshold filter extracts the portions of the input dataset whose scalars lie within the specified range. This filter operates on either point-centered or cell-centered data. This filter operates on any type of dataset and produces unstructured grid output.
To select between these two options, select either Point Data or Cell Data from the Attribute Mode menu. Once the Attribute Mode has been selected, choose the scalar array from which to threshold the data from the Scalars menu. The Lower Threshold and Upper Threshold sliders determine the range of the scalars to retain in the output. The All Scalars check box only takes effect when the Attribute Mode is set to Point Data. If the All Scalars option is checked, then a cell will only be passed to the output if the scalar values of all of its points lie within the range indicated by the Lower Threshold and Upper Threshold sliders. If unchecked, then a cell will be added to the output if the specified scalar value for any of its points is within the chosen range.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Threshold filter.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputScalars
StringVectorProperty.label: Scalars
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property contains the name of the scalar array from which to perform thresholding.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: ThresholdBetween
DoubleVectorProperty.label: Threshold Range
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The values of this property specify the upper and lower bounds of the thresholding operation.

IntVectorProperty.name: AllScalars
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If the value of this property is 1, then a cell is only included in the output if the value of the selected array for all its points is within the threshold. This is only relevant when thresholding by a point-centered array.

SourceProxy.name: Contour

Documentation.long_help: Generate isolines or isosurfaces using point scalars.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Contour filter computes isolines or isosurfaces using a selected point-centered scalar array. The Contour filter operates on any type of data set, but the input is required to have at least one point-centered scalar (single-component) array. The output of this filter is polygonal.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input dataset to be used by the contour filter.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputScalars
StringVectorProperty.label: Contour By
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the name of the scalar array from which the contour filter will compute isolines and/or isosurfaces.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: ContourValues
DoubleVectorProperty.label: Isosurfaces
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the values at which to compute isosurfaces/isolines and also the number of such values.

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeNormals
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If this property is set to 1, a scalar array containing a normal value at each point in the isosurface or isoline will be created by the contour filter; otherwise an array of normals will not be computed. This operation is fairly expensive both in terms of computation time and memory required, so if the output dataset produced by the contour filter will be processed by filters that modify the dataset's topology or geometry, it may be wise to set the value of this property to 0. Select whether to compute normals.

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeGradients
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If this property is set to 1, a scalar array containing a gradient value at each point in the isosurface or isoline will be created by this filter; otherwise an array of gradients will not be computed. This operation is fairly expensive both in terms of computation time and memory required, so if the output dataset produced by the contour filter will be processed by filters that modify the dataset's topology or geometry, it may be wise to set the value of this property to 0. Not that if ComputeNormals is set to 1, then gradients will have to be calculated, but they will only be stored in the output dataset if ComputeGradients is also set to 1.

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeScalars
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If this property is set to 1, an array of scalars (containing the contour value) will be added to the output dataset. If set to 0, the output will not contain this array.

SourceProxy.name: Glyph

Documentation.long_help: This filter generates an arrow, cone, cube, cylinder, line, sphere, or 2D glyph at each point of the input data set. The glyphs can be oriented and scaled by point attributes of the input dataset.
Documentation.short_help: Generate a glyph symbol at each point of the input data set.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Glyph filter generates a glyph (i.e., an arrow, cone, cube, cylinder, line, sphere, or 2D glyph) at each point in the input dataset. The glyphs can be oriented and scaled by the input point-centered scalars and vectors. The Glyph filter operates on any type of data set. Its output is polygonal. This filter is available on the Toolbar.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Glyph filter. This is the dataset to which the glyphs will be applied.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputScalars
StringVectorProperty.label: Scalars
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the name of the scalar array on which to operate. The indicated array may be used for scaling the glyphs. (See the SetScaleMode property.)

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputVectors
StringVectorProperty.label: Vectors
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the name of the vector array on which to operate. The indicated array may be used for scaling and/or orienting the glyphs. (See the SetScaleMode and SetOrient properties.)

InputProperty.name: Source
InputProperty.label: Glyph Type
InputProperty.Documentation: This property determines which type of glyph will be placed at the points in the input dataset.

IntVectorProperty.label: Orient
IntVectorProperty.name: SetOrient
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If this property is set to 1, the glyphs will be oriented based on the selected vector array.

IntVectorProperty.label: Scale Mode
IntVectorProperty.name: SetScaleMode
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property specifies how/if the glyphs should be scaled based on the point-centered scalars/vectors in the input dataset.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: SetScaleFactor
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property will be used as a multiplier for scaling the glyphs before adding them to the output.

IntVectorProperty.name: MaximumNumberOfPoints
IntVectorProperty.label: Maximum Number of Points
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property specifies the maximum number of glyphs that should appear in the output dataset if the value of the UseMaskPoints property is 1. (See the UseMaskPoints property.)

IntVectorProperty.name: UseMaskPoints
IntVectorProperty.label: Mask Points
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If the value of this property is set to 1, limit the maximum number of glyphs to the value indicated by MaximumNumberOfPoints. (See the MaximumNumberOfPoints property.)

IntVectorProperty.name: RandomMode
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If the value of this property is 1, then the points to glyph are chosen randomly. Otherwise the point ids chosen are evenly spaced.

SourceProxy.name: ArbitrarySourceGlyph
SourceProxy.label: Glyph (Custom Source)

Documentation.long_help: This filter generates a glyph at each point of the input data set. The glyphs can be oriented and scaled by point attributes of the input dataset.
Documentation.short_help: Generate a glyph symbol at each point of the input data set.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Glyph filter generates a glyph at each point in the input dataset. The glyphs can be oriented and scaled by the input point-centered scalars and vectors. The Glyph filter operates on any type of data set. Its output is polygonal. This filter is available on the Toolbar.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Glyph filter. This is the dataset to which the glyphs will be applied.

InputProperty.name: Source
InputProperty.label: Glyph Type
InputProperty.Documentation: This property determines which type of glyph will be placed at the points in the input dataset.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputScalars
StringVectorProperty.label: Scalars
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the name of the scalar array on which to operate. The indicated array may be used for scaling the glyphs. (See the SetScaleMode property.)

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputVectors
StringVectorProperty.label: Vectors
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the name of the vector array on which to operate. The indicated array may be used for scaling and/or orienting the glyphs. (See the SetScaleMode and SetOrient properties.)

IntVectorProperty.label: Orient
IntVectorProperty.name: SetOrient
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If this property is set to 1, the glyphs will be oriented based on the selected vector array.

IntVectorProperty.label: Scale Mode
IntVectorProperty.name: SetScaleMode
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property specifies how/if the glyphs should be scaled based on the point-centered scalars/vectors in the input dataset.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: SetScaleFactor
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property will be used as a multiplier for scaling the glyphs before adding them to the output.

IntVectorProperty.name: MaximumNumberOfPoints
IntVectorProperty.label: Maximum Number of Points
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property specifies the maximum number of glyphs that should appear in the output dataset if the value of the UseMaskPoints property is 1. (See the UseMaskPoints property.)

IntVectorProperty.name: UseMaskPoints
IntVectorProperty.label: Mask Points
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If the value of this property is set to 1, limit the maximum number of glyphs to the value indicated by MaximumNumberOfPoints. (See the MaximumNumberOfPoints property.)

IntVectorProperty.name: RandomMode
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If the value of this property is 1, then the points to glyph are chosen randomly. Otherwise the point ids chosen are evenly spaced.

SourceProxy.name: ExtractGrid
SourceProxy.label: Extract Subset

Documentation.long_help: Extract a subgrid from a structured grid with the option of setting subsample strides.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Extract Grid filter returns a subgrid of a structured input data set (uniform rectilinear, curvilinear, or nonuniform rectilinear). The output data set type of this filter is the same as the input type.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Extract Grid filter.

IntVectorProperty.name: VOI
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the minimum and maximum point indices along each of the I, J, and K axes; these values indicate the volume of interest (VOI). The output will have the (I,J,K) extent specified here.

IntVectorProperty.name: SampleRateI
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the sampling rate in the I dimension. A value grater than 1 results in subsampling; every nth index will be included in the output.

IntVectorProperty.name: SampleRateJ
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the sampling rate in the J dimension. A value grater than 1 results in subsampling; every nth index will be included in the output.

IntVectorProperty.name: SampleRateK
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the sampling rate in the K dimension. A value grater than 1 results in subsampling; every nth index will be included in the output.

IntVectorProperty.name: IncludeBoundary
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If the value of this property is 1, then if the sample rate in any dimension is greater than 1, the boundary indices of the input dataset will be passed to the output even if the boundary extent is not an even multiple of the sample rate in a given dimension.

SourceProxy.name: ProbePoint
SourceProxy.label: Probe Location

Documentation.long_help: Sample data attributes at the points in a point cloud.
Documentation.short_help: Sample data values at the points in a point cloud.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Probe filter samples the data set attributes of the current data set at the points in a point cloud. The Probe filter uses interpolation to determine the values at the selected point, whether or not it lies at an input point. The Probe filter operates on any type of data and produces polygonal output (a point cloud).

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the dataset from which to obtain probe values.

InputProperty.name: Source
InputProperty.label: Probe Type
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the dataset whose geometry will be used in determining positions to probe.

SourceProxy.name: ProbeLine
SourceProxy.label: Plot Over Line

Documentation.long_help: Sample data attributes at the points along a line. Probed lines will be displayed in a graph of the attributes.
Documentation.short_help: Sample data values at the points along a line.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Plot Over Line filter samples the data set attributes of the current data set at the points along a line. The values of the point-centered variables along that line will be displayed in an XY Plot. This filter uses interpolation to determine the values at the selected point, whether or not it lies at an input point. The Probe filter operates on any type of data and produces polygonal output (a line).

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the dataset from which to obtain probe values.

InputProperty.name: Source
InputProperty.label: Probe Type
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the dataset whose geometry will be used in determining positions to probe.

SourceProxy.name: Probe
SourceProxy.label: Resample With Dataset

Documentation.long_help: Sample data attributes at the points of a dataset.
Documentation.short_help: Sample data values at the points of a dataset.

SourceProxy.Documentation: Probe is a filter that computes point attributes at specified point positions. The filter has two inputs: the Input and Source. The Input geometric structure is passed through the filter. The point attributes are computed at the Input point positions by interpolating into the source data. For example, we can compute data values on a plane (plane specified as Input) from a volume (Source). The cell data of the source data is copied to the output based on in which source cell each input point is. If an array of the same name existsboth in source's point and cell data, only the one from the point data is probed.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the dataset from which to obtain probe values.

InputProperty.name: Source
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the dataset whose geometry will be used in determining positions to probe.

SourceProxy.name: StreamTracer
SourceProxy.label: Stream Tracer

Documentation.long_help: Integrate streamlines in a vector field.
Documentation.short_help: Integrate streamlines in a vector field.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Stream Tracer filter generates streamlines in a vector field from a collection of seed points. Production of streamlines terminates if a streamline crosses the exterior boundary of the input dataset. Other reasons for termination are listed for the MaximumNumberOfSteps, TerminalSpeed, and MaximumPropagation properties. This filter operates on any type of dataset, provided it has point-centered vectors. The output is polygonal data containing polylines.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the Stream Tracer filter.

InputProperty.name: Source
InputProperty.label: Seed Type
InputProperty.Documentation: The value of this property determines how the seeds for the streamlines will be generated.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputVectors
StringVectorProperty.label: Vectors
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property contains the name of the vector array from which to generate streamlines.

IntVectorProperty.name: MaximumPropagationUnit
IntVectorProperty.label: Max. Propagation Unit
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the unit for specifying the maximum streamline length. The Time (0) unit is the time a particle would travel with steady flow. The Length (1) unit is specified in the dataset's spatial coordinates.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: MaximumPropagation
DoubleVectorProperty.label: Max. Propagation
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property specifies the maximum streamline length. If the streamline length goes beyond this value, integration of that strealine terminates.

IntVectorProperty.name: InitialIntegrationStepUnit
IntVectorProperty.label: Initial Step Unit
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the unit for specifying the initial integration step. The Time (0) and Length (1) units have the same meaning as that specified in the MaximumPropagationUnit property. The Cell Length (2) unit specifies the step length as a number of cells.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: InitialIntegrationStep
DoubleVectorProperty.label: Initial Step Length
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property specifies the initial integration step. For non-adaptive integrators, Runge-Kutta 2 and 4, the initial step size is used throughout the integration.

IntVectorProperty.name: IntegrationDirection
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This property determines in which direction(s) the stream trace will be generated.

IntVectorProperty.name: IntegratorType
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This property determines which calculation to use for integration.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: MaximumError
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the maximum error allowed in the integration. The meaning of this value depends on the integrator chosen. The Runge-Kutta 4-5 integrator tries to choose the step size so that the estimated error is less than the value of this property.

IntVectorProperty.name: MinimumIntegrationStepUnit
IntVectorProperty.label: Minimum Step Unit
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If the Runge-Kutta 4-5 integrator is selected (IntegratorType property), this property determines the unit to use for specifying the minimum integration step. Time (0), Length (1), and Cell Length (2) have the same meanings as those indicated for the InitialIntegrationStepUnit property.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: MinimumIntegrationStep
DoubleVectorProperty.label: Minimum Step Length
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: If using the Runge-Kutta 4-5 ingrator (IntegratorType property), this property specifies the minimum integration step.

IntVectorProperty.name: MaximumIntegrationStepUnit
IntVectorProperty.label: Maximum Step Unit
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If the Runge-Kutta 4-5 integrator is selected (IntegratorType property), this property determines the unit to use for specifying the maximum integration step. Time (0), Length (1), and Cell Length (2) have the same meanings as those indicated for the InitialIntegrationStepUnit property.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: MaximumIntegrationStep
DoubleVectorProperty.label: Maximum Step Length
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: If using the Runge-Kutta 4-5 ingrator (IntegratorType property), this property specifies the minimum integration step.

IntVectorProperty.name: MaximumNumberOfSteps
IntVectorProperty.label: Max. Steps
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If the integration takes more steps to complete than indicated by this property, the integration terminates.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: TerminalSpeed
DoubleVectorProperty.label: Term. Speed
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: If at any point the speed is below the value of this property, the integration is terminated.

SourceProxy.name: TemporalCache
SourceProxy.label: Temporal Cache

Documentation.long_help: Saves a copy of the data set for a fixed number of time steps.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Temporal Cache can be used to save multiple copies of a data set at different time steps to prevent thrashing in the pipeline caused by downstream filters that adjust the requested time step. For example, assume that there is a downstream Temporal Interpolator filter. This filter will (usually) request two time steps from the upstream filters, which in turn (usually) causes the upstream filters to run twice, once for each time step. The next time the interpolator requests the same two time steps, they might force the upstream filters to re-evaluate the same two time steps. The Temporal Cache can keep copies of both of these time steps and provide the requested data without having to run upstream filters.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input of the Temporal Cache filter.

IntVectorProperty.name: CacheSize
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The cache size determines the number of time steps that can be cached at one time. The maximum number is 10. The minimum is 2 (since it makes little sense to cache less than that).

SourceProxy.name: TemporalInterpolator
SourceProxy.label: Temporal Interpolator

Documentation.long_help: Interpolate between time steps.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Temporal Interpolator converts data that is defined at discrete time steps to one that is defined over a continuum of time by linearly interpolating the data's field data between two adjacent time steps. The interpolated values are a simple approximation and should not be interpreted as anything more. The Temporal Interpolator assumes that the topology between adjacent time steps does not change.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input of the Temporal Interpolator.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: DiscreteTimeStepInterval
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: If Discrete Time Step Interval is set to 0, then the Temporal Interpolator will provide a continuous region of time on its output. If set to anything else, then the output will define a finite set of time points on its output, each spaced by the Discrete Time Step Interval. The output will have (time range)/(discrete time step interval) time steps. (Note that the time range is defined by the time range of the data of the input filter, which may be different from other pipeline objects or the range defined in the animation inspector.) This is a useful option to use if you have a dataset with one missing time step and wish to 'file-in' the missing data with an interpolated value from the steps on either side.

IntVectorProperty.name: SnapMode
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Determine which time step to snap to.

SourceProxy.name: TemporalShiftScale
SourceProxy.label: Temporal Shift Scale

Documentation.long_help: Shift and scale time values.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Temporal Shift Scale filter linearly transforms the time values of a pipeline object by applying a shift and then scale. Given a data at time t on the input, it will be transformed to time t*Shift + Scale on the output. Inversely, if this filter has a request for time t, it will request time (t-Shift)/Scale on its input.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: The input to the Temporal Shift Scale filter.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: PostShift
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The amount of time the input is shifted.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Scale
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The factor by which the input time is scaled.

SourceProxy.name: TemporalStatistics
SourceProxy.label: Temporal Statistics

Documentation.long_help: Loads in all time steps of a data set and computes some statistics about how each point and cell variable changes over time.

SourceProxy.Documentation:
Given an input that changes over time, vtkTemporalStatistics looks at the data for each time step and computes some statistical information of how a point or cell variable changes over time. For example, vtkTemporalStatistics can compute the average value of "pressure" over time of each point.
Note that this filter will require the upstream filter to be run on every time step that it reports that it can compute. This may be a time consuming operation.
vtkTemporalStatistics ignores the temporal spacing. Each timestep will be weighted the same regardless of how long of an interval it is to the next timestep. Thus, the average statistic may be quite different from an integration of the variable if the time spacing varies.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Temporal Statistics filter.

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeAverage
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Compute the average of each point and cell variable over time.

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeMinimum
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Compute the minimum of each point and cell variable over time.

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeMaximum
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Compute the maximum of each point and cell variable over time.

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeStandardDeviation
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Compute the standard deviation of each point and cell variable over time.

SourceProxy.name: ParticlePathLines
SourceProxy.label: Particle Pathlines

Documentation.long_help: Creates polylines representing pathlines of animating particles

SourceProxy.Documentation: Creates polylines representing pathlines of animating particles

DoubleVectorProperty.name: MaxStepDistance
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Prevent spurious trails from wrapping around datasets or jumping between particles by limiting the distance allowed.)

StringVectorProperty.name: IdChannelArray

SourceProxy.name: ParticleTracer

Documentation.long_help: Trace Particles through time in a vector field.
Documentation.short_help: Trace Particles through time in a vector field.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Particle Trace filter generates pathlines in a vector field from a collection of seed points. The vector field used is selected from the Vectors menu, so the input data set is required to have point-centered vectors. The Seed portion of the interface allows you to select whether the seed points for this integration lie in a point cloud or along a line. Depending on which is selected, the appropriate 3D widget (point or line widget) is displayed along with traditional user interface controls for positioning the point cloud or line within the data set. Instructions for using the 3D widgets and the corresponding manual controls can be found in section 7.4. This filter operates on any type of data set, provided it has point-centered vectors. The output is polygonal data containing polylines. This filter is available on the Toolbar.

IntVectorProperty.name: StaticSeeds
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Force the use of static seed optimizations

IntVectorProperty.name: StaticMesh
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Force the use of static mesh optimizations

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeVorticity
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Compute vorticity and angular rotation of particles as they progress

IntVectorProperty.name: TerminationTimeUnit
IntVectorProperty.label: Termination Time Unit
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The termination time may be specified as TimeSteps or Simulation time

DoubleVectorProperty.name: TerminalSpeed
DoubleVectorProperty.label: Term. Speed
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: If at any point the speed is below the value of this property, the integration is terminated.

IntVectorProperty.name: IgnorePipelineTime
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Ignore the TIME_ requests made by the pipeline and only use the TimeStep set manually

StringVectorProperty.name: ParticleFileName
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: Provide a name for the particle file generated if writing is enabled

IntVectorProperty.name: EnableParticleWriting
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Turn On/Off particle writing

SourceProxy.name: StructuredGridOutlineFilter
SourceProxy.label: Outline (curvilinear)

Documentation.long_help: This filter generates an outline representation of the input.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Outline filter generates an outline of the outside edges of the input dataset, rather than the dataset's bounding box. This filter operates on structured grid datasets and produces polygonal output.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the outline (curvilinear) filter.

SourceProxy.name: GenericClip
SourceProxy.label: Clip (Generic Datasets)

Documentation.long_help: Clip with an implicit plane, sphere or with scalars. Clipping does not reduce the dimensionality of the data set. This output data type of this filter is always an unstructured grid.
Documentation.short_help: Clip with an implicit plane, sphere or with scalars.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Generic Clip filter cuts away a portion of the input data set using a plane, a sphere, a box, or a scalar value. The menu in the Clip Function portion of the interface allows the user to select which implicit function to use or whether to clip using a scalar value. Making this selection loads the appropriate user interface. For the implicit functions, the appropriate 3D widget (plane, sphere, or box) is also displayed. The use of these 3D widgets, including their user interface components, is discussed in section 7.4. If an implicit function is selected, the clip filter returns that portion of the input data set that lies inside the function. If Scalars is selected, then the user must specify a scalar array to clip according to. The clip filter will return the portions of the data set whose value in the selected Scalars array is larger than the Clip value. Regardless of the selection from the Clip Function menu, if the Inside Out option is checked, the opposite portions of the data set will be returned. This filter operates on all types of data sets, and it returns unstructured grid data on output.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Generic Clip filter.

ProxyProperty.name: ClipFunction
ProxyProperty.label: Clip Type
ProxyProperty.Documentation: Set the parameters of the clip function.

IntVectorProperty.name: InsideOut
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Choose which portion of the dataset should be clipped away.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Value
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: If clipping with a scalar array, choose the clipping value.

SourceProxy.name: GenericContour
SourceProxy.label: Contour (Generic Datasets)

Documentation.long_help: Generate isolines or isosurfaces using point scalars.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Generic Contour filter computes isolines or isosurfaces using a selected point-centered scalar array. The available scalar arrays are listed in the Scalars menu. The scalar range of the selected array will be displayed. The interface for adding contour values is very similar to the one for selecting cut offsets (in the Cut filter). To add a single contour value, select the value from the New Value slider in the Add value portion of the interface and click the Add button, or press Enter. To instead add several evenly spaced contours, use the controls in the Generate range of values section. Select the number of contour values to generate using the Number of Values slider. The Range slider controls the interval in which to generate the contour values. Once the number of values and range have been selected, click the Generate button. The new values will be added to the Contour Values list. To delete a value from the Contour Values list, select the value and click the Delete button. (If no value is selected, the last value in the list will be removed.) Clicking the Delete All button removes all the values in the list. If no values are in the Contour Values list when Accept is pressed, the current value of the New Value slider will be used. In addition to selecting contour values, you can also select additional computations to perform. If any of Compute Normals, Compute Gradients, or Compute Scalars is selected, the appropriate computation will be performed, and a corresponding point-centered array will be added to the output. The Generic Contour filter operates on a generic data set, but the input is required to have at least one point-centered scalar (single-component) array. The output of this filter is polygonal.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Generic Contour filter.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: ContourValues
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Specify the current contour values.

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeNormals
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Select whether to compute normals.

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeGradients
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Select whether to compute gradients.

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeScalars
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Select whether to compute scalars.

SourceProxy.name: GenericCut
SourceProxy.label: Slice (Generic Datasets)

Documentation.long_help: This filter cuts a data set with a plane or sphere. Cutting is similar to a contour. It creates surfaces from volumes and lines from surfaces.
Documentation.short_help: Cut datasets with planes or spheres.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Generic Cut filter extracts the portion of the input data set that lies along the specified plane or sphere. From the Cut Function menu, you can select whether cutting will be performed with a plane or a sphere. The appropriate 3D widget (plane widget or sphere widget) will be displayed. The parameters of the cut function can be specified interactively using the 3D widget or manually using the traditional user interface controls. Instructions for using these 3D widgets and their corresponding user interfaces are found in section 7.4. By default, the cut lies on the specified plane or sphere. Using the Cut Offset Values portion of the interface, it is also possible to cut the data set at some offset from the original cut function. The Cut Offset Values are in the spatial units of the data set. To add a single offset, select the value from the New Value slider in the Add value portion of the interface and click the Add button, or press Enter. To instead add several evenly spaced offsets, use the controls in the Generate range of values section. Select the number of offsets to generate using the Number of Values slider. The Range slider controls the interval in which to generate the offsets. Once the number of values and range have been selected, click the Generate button. The new offsets will be added to the Offset Values list. To delete a value from the Cut Offset Values list, select the value and click the Delete button. (If no value is selected, the last value in the list will be removed.) Clicking the Delete All button removes all the values in the list. The Generic Cut filter takes a generic dataset as input. Use the Input menu to choose a data set to cut. The output of this filter is polygonal data.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Generic Cut filter.

ProxyProperty.name: CutFunction
ProxyProperty.label: Cut Type
ProxyProperty.Documentation: Set the parameters to the implicit function used for cutting.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: ContourValues
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Specify a list of current offset values. This can be used to create multiple cuts with different centers. Each entry represents a new cut with center shifted by the offset value.

SourceProxy.name: GenericStreamTracer
SourceProxy.label: Stream Tracer (Generic Datasets)

Documentation.long_help: Integrate streamlines in a vector field.
Documentation.short_help: Integrate streamlines in a vector field.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Generic Stream Tracer filter generates streamlines in a vector field from a collection of seed points. The vector field used is selected from the Vectors menu, so the input data set is required to have point-centered vectors. The Seed portion of the interface allows you to select whether the seed points for this integration lie in a point cloud or along a line. Depending on which is selected, the appropriate 3D widget (point or line widget) is displayed along with traditional user interface controls for positioning the point cloud or line within the data set. Instructions for using the 3D widgets and the corresponding manual controls can be found in section 7.4. The Max. Propagation entry box allows you to specify the maximum length of the streamlines. From the Max. Propagation menu, you can select the units to be either Time (the time a particle would travel with steady flow) or Length (in the data set's spatial coordinates). The Init. Step Len. menu and entry specify the initial step size for integration. (For non-adaptive integrators, Runge-Kutta 2 and 4, the initial step size is used throughout the integration.) The menu allows you to specify the units. Time and Length have the same meaning as for Max. Propagation. Cell Length specifies the step length as a number of cells. The Integration Direction menu determines in which direction(s) the stream trace will be generated: FORWARD, BACKWARD, or BOTH. The Integrator Type section of the interface determines which calculation to use for integration: Runge-Kutta 2, Runge-Kutta 4, or Runge-Kutta 4-5. If Runge-Kutta 4-5 is selected, controls are displayed for specifying the minimum and maximum step length and the maximum error. The controls for specifying Min. Step Len. and Max. Step Len. are the same as those for Init. Step Len. The Runge-Kutta 4-5 integrator tries to choose the step size so that the estimated error is less than the value of the Maximum Error entry. If the integration takes more than Max. Steps to complete, if the speed goes below Term. Speed, if Max. Propagation is reached, or if a boundary of the input data set is crossed, integration terminates. This filter operates on any type of data set, provided it has point-centered vectors. The output is polygonal data containing polylines.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Generic Stream Tracer filter.

InputProperty.name: Source
InputProperty.Documentation: Specify the seed points for generating the streamlines.

DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Specify the maximum streamline length.

IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Choose the unit for specifying the initial integration step.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: InitialIntegrationStep
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Specify the initial integration step.

IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Choose the integration direction.

IntVectorProperty.name: IntegratorType
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Choose the type of integrator to use.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: MaximumError
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Set the maximum error allowed in the integration. The meaning of this value depends on the integrator chosen.

IntVectorProperty.name: MinimumIntegrationStepUnit
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Choose the unit to use for specifying the minimum integration step.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: MinimumIntegrationStep
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Specify the minimum integration step.

IntVectorProperty.name: MaximumIntegrationStepUnit
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Choose the unit to use for specifying the maximum integration step.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: MaximumIntegrationStep
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Specify the maximum integration step.

SourceProxy.name: CTHFragmentConnect
SourceProxy.label: Extract CTH Fragments

Documentation.long_help: The CTH Extract Fragments filter finds volumes in the input data containg material above a certain material fraction.
Documentation.short_help: The CTH Extract Fragments filter finds volumes in the input data containg material above a certain material fraction.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The CTH Extract Fragments filter finds voxels inside of which a material fraction (or normalized amount of material) is higher than a given threshold. As these voxels are identified surfaces enclosing adjacent voxels above the threshold are generated. The resulting volume and its surface are what we call a fragment. The filter has the ability to compute various volumetric attributes such as fragment volume, mass, center of mass as well as volume and mass weighted averages for any of the fields present. Any field selected for such computation will be also be coppied into the fragment surface's point data for visualization. The filter also has the ability to generate Oriented Bounding Boxes (OBB) for each fragment. The data generated by the filter is organized in three outputs. The "geometry" output, containing the fragment surfaces. The "statistics" output, containing a point set of the centers of mass. The "obb representaion" output, containing OBB representations (poly data). All computed attributes are coppied into the statistics and geometry output. The obb representation output is used for validation and debugging puproses and is turned off by default.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Input to the filter can be a hierarchical box data set containing image data provided by the CTH reader.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectMaterialArray
StringVectorProperty.label: Select Material Fraction Arrays
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: Material fraction is defined as normalized amount of material per voxel. It is expected that arrays containing material fraction data has been down converted to a unsigned char.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: MaterialFractionThreshold
DoubleVectorProperty.label: Material Fraction Threshold
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Material fraction is defined as normalized amount of material per voxel. Any voxel in the input data set with a material fraction greater than this value is included in the output data set.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectMassArray
StringVectorProperty.label: Select Mass Arrays
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: Mass arrays are paired with material fraction arrays. This means that the first selected material fraction array is paired with the first selected mass array, and so on sequentially. As the filter identifies voxels meeting the minimum material fraction threshold, these voxel's mass will be used in fragment center of mass and mass calculation. A warning is generated if no mass array is selected for an individual material fraction array. However, in that case the filter will run without issue because the statistics output can be generated using fragments' centers computed from axis aligned bounding boxes.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectVolumeWtdAvgArray
StringVectorProperty.label: Compute volume weighted average over:
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: Specifies the arrays from which to volume weighted average.
For arrays selected a volume weighted average is computed. The values of these arrays are also coppied into fragment geometry cell data as the fragment surfaces are generated.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectMassWtdAvgArray
StringVectorProperty.label: Compute mass weighted average over:
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: For arrays selected a mass weighted average is computed. These arrays are also coppied into fragment geometry cell data as the fragment surfaces are generated.

IntVectorProperty.name: ComputeOBB
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Compute Object Oriented Bounding boxes (OBB). When active the result of this computation is coppied into the statistics output. In the case that the filter is built in its validation mode, the OBB's are rendered.

IntVectorProperty.name: WriteGeometryOutput
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If this property is set, then the geometry output is written to a text file. The file name will be coonstructed using the path in the "Output Base Name" widget.

IntVectorProperty.name: WriteStatisticsOutput
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If this property is set, then the statistics output is written to a text file. The file name will be coonstructed using the path in the "Output Base Name" widget.

StringVectorProperty.name: OutputBaseName
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the base including path of where to write the statistics and gemoetry output text files. It follows the pattern "/path/to/folder/and/file" here file has no extention, as the filter will generate a unique extention.

SourceProxy.name: CTHFragmentIntersect
SourceProxy.label: Intersect CTH Fragments

Documentation.long_help: The Intersect CTH Fragments filter perform geometric intersections on sets of fragments.
Documentation.short_help: The Intersect CTH Fragments filter perform geometric intersections on sets of fragments.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Intersect CTH Fragments filter perform geometric intersections on sets of fragments. The filter takes two inputs, the first containing fragment geometry and the second containing fragment centers. The filter has two outputs. The first is geometry that results from the intersection. The second is a set of points that is an approximation of the center of where each fragment has been intersected.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This input must contian fragment geometry.

InputProperty.name: Source
InputProperty.Documentation: This input must contian fragment centers.

ProxyProperty.name: CutFunction
ProxyProperty.label: Slice Type
ProxyProperty.Documentation: This property sets the type of intersecting geometry, and associated parameters.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Geoemtry Filter.

IntVectorProperty.name: UseStrips
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Toggle whether to generate faces containing triangle strips. This should render faster and use less memory, but no cell data is copied.

IntVectorProperty.name: ForceStrips
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This makes UseStrips call Modified() after changing its setting to ensure that the filter's output is immediatley changed.

IntVectorProperty.name: UseOutline
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Toggle whether to generate an outline or a surface.

IntVectorProperty.name: PassThroughIds
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If on, the output polygonal dataset will have a celldata array that holds the cell index of the original 3D cell that produced each output cell. This is useful for cell picking.

IntVectorProperty.name: PassThroughPointIds
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If on, the output polygonal dataset will have a pointdata array that holds the point index of the original 3D vertex that produced each output vertex. This is useful for picking.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Ordered Composite Distributor filter.

IntVectorProperty.name: PassThrough
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Toggle whether to pass the data through without compositing.

ProxyProperty.name: PKdTree
ProxyProperty.Documentation: Set the vtkPKdTree to distribute with.

StringVectorProperty.name: OutputType
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: When not empty, the output will be converted to the given type.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Update Suppressor filter.

IntVectorProperty.name: Enabled
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Toggle whether the update suppressor is enabled.

SourceProxy.name: CacheKeeper
SourceProxy.Documentation: vtkPVCacheKeeper manages data cache for flip book animations. When caching is disabled, this simply acts as a pass through filter. When caching is enabled, is the current time step has been previously cached then this filter shuts the update request, otherwise propagates the update and then cache the result for later use. The current time step is set using SetCacheTime().

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Update Suppressor filter.

IntVectorProperty.name: CachingEnabled
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Toggle whether the caching is enabled.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the MPI Move Data filter.

IntVectorProperty.name: MoveMode
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Specify how the data is to be redistributed.

IntVectorProperty.name: OutputDataType
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Specify the type of the dataset.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Client Server Move Data filter.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Reduction filter.

ProxyProperty.name: PreGatherHelper
ProxyProperty.Documentation: Set the algorithm that runs on each node in parallel.

ProxyProperty.name: PostGatherHelper
ProxyProperty.Documentation: Set the algorithm that takes multiple inputs and produces a single reduced output.

IntVectorProperty.name: PassThrough
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If set to a non-negative value, then produce results using only the node Id specified.

IntVectorProperty.name: GenerateProcessIds
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If true, the filter will generate vtkOriginalProcessIds arrays indicating the process id on which the cell/point was generated.

SourceProxy.name: ScatterPlot
SourceProxy.label: Scatter Plot

Documentation.long_help: Creates a scatter plot from a dataset.
Documentation.short_help: Creates a scatter plot from a dataset.

SourceProxy.Documentation: This filter creates a scatter plot from a dataset. In point data mode, it uses the X point coordinates as the default X array. All other arrays are passed to the output and can be used in the scatter plot. In cell data mode, the first single component array is used as the default X array.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the filter.

SourceProxy.name: RectilinearGridGeometryFilter

Documentation.long_help: Extracts geometry for a rectilinear grid. Output is a polydata dataset.
Documentation.short_help: Extracts geometry for a rectilinear grid.

SourceProxy.Documentation: RectilinearGridGeometryFilter is a filter that extracts geometry from a rectilinear grid. By specifying appropriate i-j-k indices, it is possible to extract a point, a curve, a surface, or a "volume". The volume is actually a (n x m x o) region of points. The extent specification is zero-offset. That is, the first k-plane in a 50x50x50 rectilinear grid is given by (0,49, 0,49, 0,0).

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Rectilinear Grid Geometry filter.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Texture Map to Plane filter.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Texture Map to Sphere filter.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Texture Map to Cylinder filter.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Polyline to Rectilinear Grid filter.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input to the Min Max filter.

StringVectorProperty.name: Operation
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: Select whether to perform a min, max, or sum operation on the data.

SourceProxy.name: PVExtractSelection
SourceProxy.label: Extract Selection (internal)
SourceProxy.Documentation: This filter extracts a given set of cells or points given a selection. The selection can be obtained from a rubber-band selection (either point, cell, visible or in a frustum) and passed to the filter or specified by providing an ID list. This is an internal filter, use "ExtractSelection" instead.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: The input from which the selection is extracted.

InputProperty.name: Selection
InputProperty.Documentation: The input that provides the selection object.

IntVectorProperty.name: PreserveTopology
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If this property is set to 1 the output preserves the topology of its input and adds an insidedness array to mark which cells are inside or out. If 0 then the output is an unstructured grid which contains only the subset of cells that are inside.

SourceProxy.Documentation: The Annotate Time filter can be used to show the data time in a text annotation.

InputProperty.name: Input

StringVectorProperty.name: Format
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: The value of this property is a format string used to display the input time. The format string is specified using printf style.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Shift
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The amount of time the input is shifted (after scaling).

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Scale
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: The factor by which the input time is scaled.

SourceProxy.name: CellDerivatives
SourceProxy.label: Compute Derivatives

Documentation.long_help: This filter computes derivatives of scalars and vectors.

SourceProxy.Documentation: CellDerivatives is a filter that computes derivatives of scalars and vectors at the center of cells. You can choose to generate different output including the scalar gradient (a vector), computed tensor vorticity (a vector), gradient of input vectors (a tensor), and strain matrix of the input vectors (a tensor); or you may choose to pass data through to the output.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input to the filter.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputScalars
StringVectorProperty.label: Scalars
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the name of the scalar array to differentiate.

StringVectorProperty.name: SelectInputVectors
StringVectorProperty.label: Vectors
StringVectorProperty.Documentation: This property indicates the name of the vector array to differentiate.

IntVectorProperty.name: OutputVectorType
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This property Controls how the filter works to generate vector cell data. You can choose to compute the gradient of the input scalars, or extract the vorticity of the computed vector gradient tensor. By default, the filter will take the gradient of the input scalar data.

IntVectorProperty.name: OutputTensorType
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: This property controls how the filter works to generate tensor cell data. You can choose to compute the gradient of the input vectors, or compute the strain tensor of the vector gradient tensor. By default, the filter will take the gradient of the vector data to construct a tensor.

SourceProxy.name: ExtractSelection
SourceProxy.label: Extract Selection

Documentation.long_help: Extract different type of selections.

SourceProxy.Documentation: This filter extracts a set of cells/points given a selection. The selection can be obtained from a rubber-band selection (either cell, visible or in a frustum) or threshold selection and passed to the filter or specified by providing an ID list.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: This property specifies the input from which the selection is extracted.

IntVectorProperty.name: PreserveTopology
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If this property is set to 1 the output preserves the topology of its input and adds an insidedness array to mark which cells are inside or out. If 0 then the output is an unstructured grid which contains only the subset of cells that are inside.

IntVectorProperty.name: ShowBounds
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: For frustum selection, if this property is set to 1 the output is the outline of the frustum instead of the contents of the input that lie within the frustum.

SourceProxy.name: ConvertSelection

SourceProxy.name: MergeBlocks
SourceProxy.label: Merge Blocks

Documentation.short_help: Appends vtkCompositeDataSet leaves into a single vtkUnstructuredGrid

SourceProxy.Documentation: vtkCompositeDataToUnstructuredGridFilter appends all vtkDataSet leaves of the input composite dataset to a single unstructure grid. The subtree to be combined can be choosen using the SubTreeCompositeIndex. If the SubTreeCompositeIndex is a leaf node, then no appending is required.

InputProperty.name: Input
InputProperty.Documentation: Set the input composite dataset.

IntVectorProperty.name: SubTreeCompositeIndex
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Select the index of the subtree to be appended. For now, this property is internal.
